title: A conventional grid approach?
content:
As part of my studies i am gathering information about the grid in design and the typographic grid. I need opinions from typographers on their views about a conventional grid approach.

For or Against and why

Greatly appreciate any help  
cheers
author: kel86

comments.content: Wouldnt want to start ranting myself, but Id suggest Ellen Luptons, "Thinking with Type" as a great place to start for information regarding typography and its relation to the grid.

Thanks for the suggestion  
I'll give it a go

Start off with the basic Robert Bringhurst book.

[http://www.amazon.com/Elements-Typographic-Style-Robert-Bringhurst/dp/08...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150425030218/http:/www.amazon.com/Elements-Typographic-Style-Robert-Bringhurst/dp/0881792063 "http://www.amazon.com/Elements-Typographic-Style-Robert-Bringhurst/dp/0881792063")

Then work your way in with Kimberly Elams book on the  
grid system.

[http://www.amazon.com/Grid-Systems-Principles-Organizing-Design/dp/15689...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150425030218/http:/www.amazon.com/Grid-Systems-Principles-Organizing-Design/dp/1568984650/ref=pd_bbs_sr_1?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1207028872&sr=1-1 "http://www.amazon.com/Grid-Systems-Principles-Organizing-Design/dp/1568984650/ref=pd\_bbs\_sr\_1?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1207028872&sr=1-1")

Least this is how my school puts me through and itss  
helped out a lot on my designs over the years.
